title: A projector or TV, which one is best? - Quora

response.answer_text: Each has its advantages and strengths. The correct answer to your question is- it depends on several factors. The factor that is perhaps most significant tends to be the one most often overlooked - and that is how much of your field of vision is filled by your screen. Think of the angle that is formed by the left edge of your screen, the bridge of your nose (as the vertex of the angle) and the right edge of your screen. Like all angles, that angle is measured in degrees. This angle (often referred to as FOV for Field Of View) increases as the width of the screen increases and decreases as the screen width decreases. Likewise, the closer you sit to the screen, your field of view (or rather the portion of it filled by your screen) grows larger, while the further you are, the smaller the FOV. In the end, neither your seating distance nor your screen width is critical; it’s the ratio between them, and the aforementioned angle that really matters. There are two main reasons why the FOV matters… The first has to do with something called the “immersion effect” or “induction effect”. Effectively, this is when your brain is “tricked” into regarding what’s happening on the screen as reality (as opposed to “just a movie”). If you’ve ever jumped in your seat when something on the screen startled you, or cried when something really sad happened, then you’ve experienced the immersion effect. If you’d been watching the same movie on a much smaller screen, you would have been far less likely to have been startled because you wouldn’t have been so immersed in the movie. (Note that although I refer to movies throughout this answer, all of this applies equally to TV shows, sporting events and video games.) There are several factors to the immersion effect but a field of view that is at least 30 degrees is a big one. Consider a 50″ TV (which seems to be the average/standard these days - at least for U.S. consumers)… if you’re sitting 7 feet away, your FOV is less than 30 degrees. (6.8 feet would be the maximum seating distance in order to have at least a 30 degree FOV with a 50″ screen.) The second reason that your field of view is critical has to do with visual acuity — your eye’s (finite) ability to see detail in an image. Consider two palm trees… from a mile away they may look like a single palm tree to your eyes. Likewise, two blades of grass from 100 yards away. Just like those two palm trees or blades of grass, a pair of vertical lines on a screen will look like a single line beyond a certain distance. To fully resolve all the detail in a 1080p image — to be able to distinguish 2 lines (one pixel wide, right next to each other) among 1920 of them on a 1080p image, someone with 20/20 (or corrected 20/20) vision, will need a screen that fills at least 32 degrees of their field of view. (That’s 6.3 feet from a 50″ TV.) Any added detail (e.g. UHD/“4K”) is imperceptible if your FOV is less than 32 degrees, so if you’re sitting more than 6′ 4″ from a 50″ UHD TV, you better have vision that’s better than 20/20 if you want to benefit from the increased resold a 4K image. As your FOV increases beyond 32 degrees, (whether because your screen is larger or because you’re sitting closer,) you will experience at least some benefit from a UHD/4K image. Someone with 20/20 vision will need an enormous 64 degree FOV to fully resolve all the detail in a UHD image - and that’s actually so wide as to be detrimental to the immersion effect! Both SMPTE (Society of Motion Picture and Television Engineers) and THX have recommended minimum, maximum and optimal seating distances for a given screen width. They are all based on FOV. If a movie theater wants to be “THX Certified”, someone seated in the front row of seats can have no more than a 70 degree FOV, while someone sitting in the furthest row of seats can have no less than a 26 degree FOV. There are other factors in THX certification but those two rules cannot be violated. One nice thing about the THX optimal recommendation (40 degree FOV) is that the math gets pretty easy. Assuming a screen aspect ratio of 1.78:1 (the ATSC/HDTV standard), you simply take your seating distance in feet and multiply by 10 to get the optimal screen size in inches (measured diagonally). If you sit 8′ away, you’ll want an 80″ screen. Going the other way, you divide by 10 so if you have a 55″ TV, the optimal seating distance is 5.5 feet. It’s here that we get to the crux of things. If you sit 10′ away (and want to continue to do so), then a 100″ screen is required — but a very good projector and screen will cost a fraction of what you’d pay for a 100″ TV. So budgetary factors and optimal FOV will often favor a projector and screen over a TV — but only if you have sufficient light control for a projected image. As other answers have indicated, it doesn’t take much light for a projected image to look “washed out” (even with a very bright projector) — and there’s nothing immersive about a washed out picture. Of course, there are screens that do a much better job (presenting an image that is not washed out) with fairly high levels of ambient room light, but they’re expensive. Depending on your budget and/or your ability to darken the room, the best solution may simply be to move the sofa 5′ away from your 50″ screen. Unless someone else in the house is unwilling to have the furniture arranged that way…

Projectors in contrary with television sets reflects light rather than producing light that cause strain to eyes.Flexibility or portability: Not only talking about portability, but on the other hand they're lightweight. Is a Projector or TV right for you? A projector is good for optimizing the price of your screen, building an immersive experience, and having the appeal of jaw-dropping size. A TV is brighter, and has a simple input/output situation, and also doesn’t have any bulbs to burn out. But you’ll need to understand several other things, about resolutions, the physical requirements of using a projector (spacing), and what the ease of use looks like for projectors before you can make a call. Projector vs TV: Screen Size in Relation to Price  First and foremost: are home theater projectors worth it? To do a quick pass at this, I’ll pull the best selling TVs at 3 diagonal-size price points, and two representative projectors from the high and low end of the market, all from Amazon, and see how the price-per-diagonal-inch shakes out:  Okay, so, there’s definitely some interesting things going on here. First, observe that huge jump in the 55, to 65, to 75 inch Television panels. There’s the price-point island I was talking about: from 55” to 65” the price increases more than 130%. And what are you getting for that? A big panel, sure, but note that both projectors are capable of 120”. Literally more than double 55”. Report this ad Projectors, like TVs, have high and low price points. Because of that, you’ll be able to find a TV or Projector to fit your budget no matter how large it is. But think about the high end projector for a moment. It’s obvious that, at 120” diagonal, it costs much less per diagonal inch than the 75” Television panel. But what about if we restricted the high end projector to projecting a 75” screen–hold it to the same standard as the 75” panel–and ran the numbers that way? You can see in the table that, even the higher end projector setup to project a 75” screen is more cost effective than the 75” Television What about the low end projector? If the high end projector is cost-effective, even when projecting 75”, we know the low end projector will be. But what about if we compare the low end projector maximum projection size to the high end Televisions? If you look at the price per diagonal inch, when comparing the low end projector to either the 65” or the 75” panel, we can say the following: when compared to budget projectors, best-selling Televisions tend to cost double for half as much screen.

Inferable from their differed uses, projectors have turned into the most looked for after electronic hardware. In spite of the fact that, a particular projector may not satisfy every one of your needs, there are some that can be utilized for both home just as office use. While at home, a projector can be associated with a DVD player or set-top box to watch your preferred projects in a performance center like setting, the workplace utilization of a projector incorporates showing addresses or introductions for countless individuals.  In any case, as most other electronic devices, computerized projectors also have their own arrangement of points of interest and impediments. It is beneficial to examine these before you select a projector that will best match your needs and prerequisites. Favorable circumstances of Projectors Piqo Projector: Enormous Sized Picture: Digital projectors can be utilized to make amazingly huge measured pictures much the same as those found in a film lobby. In spite of the fact that a film projector with huge light yield can create pictures of up to 300", even generally accessible advanced projectors are equipped for delivering sharp pictures as large as 120". Bit of leeway While Creating Small Images: Even if the projector is utilized to deliver littler examined pictures of to 60", it can in any case spare you a great deal of cash when contrasted with a LCD TV of a similar size. In addition, the image at this size is exceptionally splendid and can even be utilized with a couple of lights on. Saves money on Space: A roof mount projector does not consume any space on the floor and remains for the most part inconspicuous when not being used. Indeed, even a retractable screen can be put far out when not being used, which is superior to anything a cumbersome TV that is hard to move as often as possible. As I would like to think, the best minimized projector is: This projector offers a distinctive picture at an extraordinarily short separation from the projection surface. Set it to just 5 crawls to get 60-inch full picture full picture and full picture, or go more remote to get pictures up to 100 inches. Simplicity of Installation: Other than roof mount projectors that need a specialist for establishment, an ordinary projector is anything but difficult to arrangement and should be possible absent much exertion. Impediments of Projectors Light Can Play Spoilsport: A projector works best when worked in low light conditions as the photos delivered are more clear and more splendid. This can frequently demonstrate to be a drawback when you are tending to a gathering where your group of spectators needs to record highlights. Exorbitant Maintenance: The support cost of home theater projectors is frequently on the higher side than that of a LCD TV. The light of a projector should be supplanted once in a while, contingent upon your use and the projector model.

i would not say projector can replace TV even i am a projector seller. the true is TV normally has higher resolution and contrast ratio compaired with those projectors under this price. for example, you can buy a LG HD 1080P TV for ＄136.99 on amazon, but you only get a 720P LCD projector around＄200   but some projectors can be really small and easy to carried with, and this means they can be really good for traveling. i am talking about DLP projectors. Digital Light Processing (DLP) is a display device based on optical micro-electro-mechanical technology that uses a digital micromirror device. Thanks to the DLP technology, projector can “shrink” into size of a human palm but project as good image as those regular projectors do.   This kind of device usually has built-in battery and can be charged by USB to extend the battery life. this feature really make a difference when you go out. some can even work as a power bank to charge your phone .   DLP projector usually has more powerful screen-mirroring function than TV. this projector on the photo is projecting what the phone display after wirelessly connecting and the phone works like a GamePad.  if you like to watch a movie lying on your own bed, you can just adjust the tripod and project the image on the ceiling. i haven’t seen any TV can do this.  i am not saying that you should get a projector rather than a TV. i just want to introduce new projectors here(well, especially my projector…..). my real view is they are totally different devices and they cannot replace each other and all of you are smart enough to pick what you need. BTW, you can find more information of my projector here if you are interested: Amazon.com: ExquizOn DLP Mini Projector, High Brightness Pico Video Projector Support 1080P HDMI USB TF Micro SD Card AV Ideal for Camp Backyard Outdoor Movie Night Home Cinema TV Laptop Game: Electronics

(This answer has primary relevance in the Indian market, however it may be a similar case elsewhere too) This is one of the big inequities in the Home electronics market currently, in our opinion. A decent 55″ HD TV can cost anywhere from 60–70k and above. Once you get down to serious sizes (anything over 90–100″) the costs of a HD TV are prohibitive, often costing over 2 Lakhs. And there is a natural limit to how big the TVs screen size can get. On the other hand, a HD projector from any world class brand (Epson/BenQ) is available in the 70k-1.1L range, along with a high grade screen (that can be from 90″ going all the way to 200″) costing around 20–40k, you will be able to create a great HD viewing experience for as low as 1–1.5L. Depends entirely on the application. A projector is the best choice for watching films on. There are no movie theatres or even dubbing stages in the world that use a TV as the display, primarily because TVs aren't big enough. That may change in our lifetime which could get interesting.

I do think projectors are better,as if we were to compare the features of television set and projector in the same price range.The projector not only gives you the option of a bigger screen,but it is also easy to move from room to room than a TV set.Check out this projector website for thorough reviews and tips.

“Better” is very subjective. Under proper viewing conditions, when watching movies, a projector experience could be closer to a movie theater experience; however, in terms of pure specifications most TVs are better than projectors.
I prefer a projector because it has a clearer, bigger picture in my home theater.
